sentences.sentence: A private member's bill to address environmental racism was adopted at second reading and referred to the environment committee in the House of Commons.

Bill C-230(https://www.parl.ca/DocumentViewer/en/43-1/bill/C-230/first-reading) requires the federal government to collect data(https://www.cbc.ca/news/technology/environmental-racism-bill-c-230-1.5954082) on the location of environmental hazards across the country and identify links between race, socioeconomic status and various health outcomes.

In order to do so, adequate data on race and health will be needed and this is not something that currently exists across most jurisdictions in Canada.Despite clear links between socioeconomic indicators(https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/publications/science-research-data/key-health-inequalities-canada-national-portrait-executive-summary.html) and health outcomes, few Canadian health agencies collect racial data.
This fact came under close scrutiny as the COVID-19 pandemic unfolded and the disproportionate rates of exposure and infection among racialized populations became evident.

Race-based data(https://www.publichealthontario.ca/-/media/documents/ncov/epi/2020/06/covid-19-epi-diversity.pdf?la=en) collection initiatives soon followed(https://rsc-src.ca/sites/default/files/IC19RC%20-%20EN%20-%20Race%20and%20ethnicity%20data%20collection%20during%20COVID-19%20in%20Canada%20if%20you%20are%20not%20counte.pdf).It should come as no surprise that data on the links between race and health outcomes remain scant.

Canada has long hesitated to collect race-based data - a hesitation based in part on fear that it could lead to targeted discrimination.This fear is not without merit: identifying and sorting people by race has been used to facilitate some of the most horrific and unjustifiable crimes against humanity - the Holocaust being a prime example.

Out of recognition of this fact, neither Germany nor France(https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/jun/16/france-and-germany-urged-to-rethink-reluctance-to-gather-ethnicity-data) collect data on race or ethnicity across social institutions or outcomes, and have resisted doing so for decades.
These decisions, however, have been increasingly questioned as calls to identify and address racial inequality have increased.Canada has also come under pressure to change the way it collects data.

A statement released by(https://www.canada.ca/en/canadian-heritage/corporate/transparency/open-government/standing-committee/chagger-whole-senate-addressing-ending-systemic-racism/statement-parliamentary-black-caucus.html) the Parliamentary Black Caucus in June 2020 urged the Government of Canada to collect race-based data.

Later that summer, Statistics Canada and the Canadian Association of Chiefs of Police announced plans to(https://www.statcan.gc.ca/eng/about/smr09/smr09_106) add the collection of data on race and Indigenous status to police-reported crime statistics.

Providing it is done properly, this is a welcome move and will help us better contextualize the over-representation of Black and Indigenous groups observed in the criminal justice system.More is needed, however.

If we would like to know the underlying reasons why Black and Indigenous people are over-represented in our prison systems(https://www.thestar.com/politics/federal/2021/03/04/too-many-black-and-indigenous-people-are-in-prison-researchers-say-mandatory-minimum-sentences-are-part-of-the-problem.html), for example, then we need race-based data on other social outcomes, including in the areas of housing, education and employment.Perhaps surprisingly, efforts to advance equality in the employment sector are partly to blame for a lack of racially disaggregated data in Canada.

The Employment Equity Act of 1986, and the Employment Equity Act of 1995, formalized the use of the "visible minority" concept across the federal public service, in an attempt to address employment discrimination.According to the act, visible minorities are(https://laws-lois.justice.gc.ca/eng/acts/E-5.401/page-1.html#h-215135) "persons, other than Aboriginal peoples, who are non-Caucasian in race or non-white in colour."

The visible minority category (a solely Canadian concept) was subsequently adopted more widely and has become one of the primary ways of identifying and addressing non-white/non-Indigenous people in Canada.While rooted in attempts at positive discrimination, the United Nations has(https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/term-visible-minorities-may-be-discriminatory-un-body-warns-canada-1.690247) argued that the visible minority category perpetuates discrimination by lumping together diverse groups of people with diverse historical and contemporary experiences.While often used in the context of discussions about race, the category actually encompasses race, ethnicity and national origin (Statistics Canada suggests(https://www23.statcan.gc.ca/imdb/p3Var.pl?Function=DEC&;Id=45152) that the visible minority population comprises the following groups: South Asian, Chinese, Black, Filipino, Latin American, Arab, Southeast Asian, West Asian, Korean and Japanese).

For this reason, the visible minority category is a fairly useless concept, as any data produced using the concept tells us nothing about the distinct experiences of these different groups.If Canadians are going to have a full understanding of how race, along with other demographic characteristics, influence experiences in Canadian society, then we need to collect data on race across social institutions.

It's time we give up the visible minority category in flavor of more robust and comprehensive race-based data collection.National PostAkwasi Owusu-Bempah is a faculty member in the department of sociology at the University of Toronto, a special advisor to the Canadian Civil Liberties Association and co-chair of the Black North Initiative's justice committee.

Sen. Wanda Thomas Bernard is a Senator from Nova Scotia and deputy chair of the Senate human rights committee.Chris Selley: Ottawa bringing 'racial' issues into COVID vaccine rollout isn't helping anyone(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/chris-selley-ottawa-bringing-racial-issues-into-covid-vaccine-rollout-isnt-helping-anyone)NP View: Building a consensus on a more inclusive Canada(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/np-view-building-a-consensus-on-a-more-inclusive-canada) !
